query: To protect newly planted trees from herbivores, what is the evidence for the effectiveness of fencing compared to using individual tree guards or shelters?
relevant_summary: The evidence shows both fencing and individual tree guards/shelters can be effective for protecting newly planted trees from herbivores, but with varying results. For fencing to exclude large herbivores, five of ten studies found that using wire fencing increased the cover and size of understory plants, while six studies found no effect (Action 1230). Specifically for tree protection, two of three studies examining wire fencing effects on young trees found increased biomass in one case and decreased density in another, with one study showing mixed effects depending on species (Action 1230). Two replicated controlled studies found that wire fencing increased tree density (Action 1230). For fencing after tree planting, four of five studies found that using fences to exclude grazing increased survival, size and cover of planted trees, while two studies found no effect on survival rate and one found mixed effects depending on fence structure (Action 1254). For individual tree guards and shelters, one study found that light-colored but not dark-colored plastic tree shelters increased survival rates of planted tree seedlings, and tree guards increased tree height after 37 but not 44 months (Action 1268). In freshwater wetlands, fencing to exclude deer had no significant effect on total tree seedling density after three years but resulted in taller tree seedlings compared to unfenced plots (Action 3330). Plastic guards increased both height and diameter growth rates of planted baldcypress seedlings over one growing season (Action 3330). In coastal wetlands, full-length plastic shelters increased survival rates and growth of red mangrove propagules compared to no shelter, while bamboo shelters and below-ground plastic shelters had no clear effect (Action 3331).

Survival (3 studies): One replicated, paired, controlled study in floodplain swamps in Australia reported that planted swamp gum Eucalyptus camphora seedlings had a much higher survival rate, over one year, in plots fenced to exclude mammals than in open plots. query: What are the documented effects of removing competing understory vegetation on planted trees and overall forest biodiversity?
relevant_summary:
Studies show mixed effects of removing competing understory vegetation on planted trees. Five studies in Canada, USA, France, Panama and Sweden found no effect of controlling understory vegetation on emergence, survival, growth rate or frost damage in planted seedlings, though one found removing competing herbs increased seedling biomass (Action 1256). One controlled study in Canada found that removal of sheep laurel shrubs increased growth rate and height of planted black spruce seedlings (Action 1256). One study in Ghana found that removal of invasive weed species increased tree seedling height (Action 1228).

Regarding forest biodiversity effects, vegetation removal combined with mechanical soil disturbance increased cover and diversity of understory plants in Portugal and France, while decreasing understory shrub cover (Action 1274). However, mechanical removal of invasive plants showed mixed biodiversity effects: one study in Hawaii found increased understory plant biomass following invasive grass removal, while one USA study found no effect of invasive shrub removal on understory plant diversity (Action 1228).

Tree thinning, which affects vegetation dynamics, generally promotes understory biodiversity: seventeen of 25 studies found that thinning trees increased density and cover of understory plants, and thirteen of 19 studies found increased species richness and diversity of understory plants (Action 1211). Similarly, logging trees in forests increased understory plant density and cover in five of ten studies, and increased species richness and diversity in four of seven studies (Action 1273).

For mammal biodiversity, one study in Chile found that areas retaining understorey vegetation had more species and visits from medium-sized mammals compared to areas cleared of understorey vegetation (Action 2645).

query: In degraded forest areas, what interventions are available to improve soil conditions and enhance tree growth?
relevant_summary:
Several interventions are available to improve soil conditions and enhance tree growth in degraded forest areas. Ground preparation before tree planting increases survival and growth rates of planted trees according to six of seven studies (Action ID: 1263). Soil scarification or ploughing enhances germination, with two of three studies finding increased density of young trees, though effects vary by species (Action ID: 1251). Soil disturbance techniques (excluding scarification) have been used to enhance germination (Action ID: 1252).

Fertilizer applications show mixed results for tree growth enhancement. Applying fertilizer after tree planting increased tree size in two studies, though three other studies found no effect on tree size, survival rate or health (Action ID: 1260). General fertilizer use increased total plant cover, understory plant biomass, and size of young trees in six of eight studies (Action ID: 1248). Adding fertilizer alongside planting/seeding increased cover of shrubs and trees and vegetation biomass (Action ID: 1704).

Organic matter amendments provide soil improvement options. Adding organic matter such as leaf litter increased species richness of young trees in one study and increased total plant cover (Action ID: 1250). Mixed organic and inorganic soil amendments showed positive results, with studies finding higher microbial biomass and activity, increased soil organic carbon content, and improved soil structure (Action ID: 902).

Biological soil amendments offer additional benefits. Soil inoculation with bacteria or fungi resulted in higher microbial diversity, increased soil organic matter content, and higher crop yields (Action ID: 888). Mycorrhizal inoculation before seeding/planting can increase vegetation cover initially and enhance abundance of target conservation species (Action ID: 3429).

Combined vegetation removal with mechanical soil disturbance increased cover and diversity of understory plants and increased density of young trees (Action ID: 1274). However, soil enhancers excluding fertilizer showed mixed effects on tree seedling survival and height with no effect on seedling health (Action ID: 1153).

tools_called.args: {"query_string": "degraded forest soil improvement tree growth restoration", "k": 10}
{"query_string": "soil amendment fertilizer tree planting forest restoration", "k": 10}

Five studies examined the effects of inoculating soil with mycorrhiza before seeding/planting on grassland vegetation. Four studies were in the USA and one was in Germany.

VEGETATION COMMUNITY (1 STUDY)

Overall richness/diversity (1 study): One replicated, randomized, controlled study in Germany found that inoculating soil with mycorrhizal fungi and sowing seeds of grassland species did not alter plant species richness.

VEGETATION ABUNDANCE (4 STUDIES)

Overall abundance (2 studies): One replicated, randomized, paired, controlled study in the USA found that inoculating soil with mycorrhizal fungi before sowing seeds initially increased vegetation cover, but after three years, vegetation cover did not differ between areas that were and were not inoculated. One controlled study in the USA found that adding soil microbes and nutrients when planting grass plugs did not change the overall cover of herbaceous species.
Characteristic plant abundance (2 studies): One replicated, randomized, controlled study in Germany found that adding mycorrhiza to the soil and sowing seeds of grassland species increased the abundance of target species that were considered a local conservation priority. One controlled study in the USA found that adding soil microbes and nutrients when planting grass plugs increased the cover of three of 38 native prairie species.
Tree/shrub abundance (1 study): One controlled study in the USA found that adding soil microbes and nutrients when planting grass plugs did not change the cover of woody species.
Native/non-target species abundance (1 study): One replicated, controlled study in the USA found that adding mycorrhizal fungi to soil before sowing seeds did not alter the biomass of three native grass and forb species.

VEGETATION STRUCTURE (1 STUDY)

Height (1 study): One replicated, controlled study in the USA found that adding mycorrhizal fungi to soil before sowing seeds increased the height of giant sacaton plants.
Individual plant size (1 study): One replicated, controlled study in the USA found that adding mycorrhizal fungi to soil before sowing seeds did not increase the biomass of giant sacaton plants.

OTHER (1 STUDY) 

Germination/Emergence (1 study): One replicated, controlled study in the USA found that adding mycorrhizal fungi to soil before sowing seeds did not increase the emergence of giant sacaton plants."
}

Biodiversity: Five controlled trials from China and India (four also randomized and replicated), and one study from Japan found higher microbial biomass and activity in soils with a mix of manure and inorganic fertilizers. Manure alone also increased microbial biomass. One trial found increased microbial diversity.
Erosion: One controlled, replicated trial from India found that mixed amendments were more effective at reducing the size of cracks in dry soil than inorganic fertilizers alone or no fertilizer.
SOC loss: Four controlled, randomized, replicated trials and one controlled trial from China and India found more organic carbon in soils with mixed fertilizers. Manure alone also increased organic carbon. One trial also found more carbon in soil amended with inorganic fertilizers and lime.
SOM loss: Two controlled, randomized, replicated trials from China and India found more nutrients in soils with manure and inorganic fertilizers. One controlled, randomized, replicated trial from China found inconsistent effects of using mixed manure and inorganic fertilizers.
Yield: Two controlled, randomized, replicated trials from China found increased maize Zea mays yield in soils with mixed manure and inorganic fertilizer amendments.
SOIL TYPES COVERED: clay, clay loam, sandy-loam, silt clay loam, silty-loam."
}

query: What is the state of the evidence regarding the effectiveness of managing public access and tourism to mitigate human disturbance in forests?
relevant_summary: The evidence regarding the effectiveness of managing public access and tourism to mitigate human disturbance in forests is extremely limited. Most management interventions have no direct scientific evidence supporting their effectiveness. Action 2330 provides the only substantive evidence, showing that excluding or limiting visitor numbers to protected areas resulted in higher populations of medium-sized and large mammals compared to unrestricted access areas, fewer bears being killed to protect humans, and increased use of protected areas by grizzly bears and leopards. Action 312 found that fewer birds, but not fewer species, were observed as visitor numbers increased in Spanish forests, with effects largely due to decreases in collared dove and serin abundance. Action 311 showed that two wader species nested closer to or at higher densities near a path following resurfacing that resulted in fewer people leaving the path. Action 1619 found that closing paths in Australian alpine shrubland did not alter shrub cover but increased plant species numbers. For most other interventions including creating managed paths/signs to contain disturbance (Action 1170), re-routing paths or controlling access (Action 1171), restricting pedestrian access (Action 3022), installing boardwalks to prevent trampling (Action 3024), adopting ecotourism principles (Action 3025), providing paths to limit disturbance to mammals (Action 2337), voluntary agreements with locals (Action 2339), limiting recreational access (Action 2152), and restricting recreational activities to particular areas (Action 3850), no studies were found that evaluated their effectiveness.

tools_called.args: {"query_string": "forest management public access tourism human disturbance", "k": 10}

We found no intervention-based studies examining the effects of reducing visitor numbers on bird populations. This effect was largely due to decreases in collared dove Streptopelia decaocto presence and serin Serinus serinus abundance.
Remacha, C., Perez-Tris, J. & Antonio Delgado, J. (2011) Reducing visitors’ group size increases the number of birds during educational activities: Implications for management of nature-based recreation,Journal of Environmental Management, 92, 1564–1568.

'No evidence' for an action means we have not yet found any studies that directly and quantitatively tested this action during our systematic journal and report searches. }

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (2 STUDIES)

Abundance (1 study): A site comparison study in Ecuador found that a road with restricted access had a higher population of medium-sized and large mammals compared to a road with unrestricted access.
Survival (1 study): A before-and-after study in the USA found that temporarily restricting visitor access resulted in fewer bears being killed to protect humans.

BEHAVIOUR (3 STUDIES)

Use (3 studies): Three studies (one a before-and-after study), in the USA and Thailand, found that restricting human access to protected areas resulted in increased use of these areas by grizzly bears and leopards."

query: How does the effectiveness of managing livestock grazing to protect forests vary across different geographical locations mentioned in the evidence?
relevant_summary: Based on the evidence, the effectiveness of managing livestock grazing to protect forests shows geographical variation. Studies on preventing livestock grazing were conducted in Brazil, UK, Costa Rica, and Israel, with two of three studies finding increased survival, species richness and diversity of understory plants in Brazil, UK and Costa Rica, while the Israeli study showed increased density of oak seedlings and saplings (Action 1206). For shortening grazing periods, effectiveness varied by location: a study in Spain found increased abundance and size of regenerating oak trees, while an Australian study found no effect on native plant species richness, and a UK study found higher tree seedling numbers following summer compared to winter grazing (Action 1208). Studies using wire fences to exclude livestock from specific forest sections spanned Argentina, Australia, Belgium, Israel, New Zealand, Spain, West Africa and the USA, with four of eight studies finding increased biomass, species richness, density and cover of understory plants, while four showed mixed or no effects. Tree regeneration studies in Mexico, Kenya, Israel and Panama showed three of four studies finding increased size and density of regenerating trees when livestock were excluded (Action 1205). Modified grazing regimes in forest, open woodland and savanna showed mixed results across six studies in Australia and one in the USA, with varying effects on reptile diversity and abundance (Action 3492). Livestock exclusion from semi-natural habitats including woodlands showed generally positive effects across six studies in the USA, two in Spain, and one in Australia, with most studies finding higher small mammal abundances when livestock were excluded (Action 2407).

query: What management techniques involving tree removal can be used to increase forest structural diversity and what are their effects?
relevant_summary:
Several tree removal management techniques can be used to increase forest structural diversity with varying effects on different forest components. Shelterwood harvesting is an effective technique that resulted in higher plant diversity, lower grass cover and higher density of tree species compared with clearcutting (Action 1214), and six of seven studies found it increased abundance, species richness and diversity of understory plants, as well as the growth and survival rate of young trees (Action 1223). Group-selection harvesting showed mixed results, with four of eight studies finding it increased cover and diversity of understory plants and the density of young trees, while two studies found it decreased understory species richness and biomass (Action 1224). 

Tree thinning is another effective technique where seventeen of 25 studies found that thinning trees in forests increased the density and cover of understory plants, and thirteen of 19 studies found it increased species richness and diversity of understory plants (Action 1211). Thinning by girdling (cutting rings around tree trunks) increased understory plant species richness, diversity and cover (Action 1226). General logging and tree removal within forests showed more variable effects, with five of ten studies finding it increased the density and cover of understory plants, and four of seven studies finding it increased species richness and diversity of understory plants (Action 1273).

Selective or reduced impact logging had different effects on wildlife, with one review of 41 studies finding that reduced impact logging had a smaller effect on bat abundance than conventional logging (Action 989). Thinning within forests also benefited other wildlife, with five of six studies finding higher overall bat activity in thinned or thinned and burned forest than unthinned forest (Action 991), and four studies finding that coniferous woodland thinned with prescribed burning, mulching or nearby felling had greater species richness of butterflies than unmanaged woodland (Action 3940).

One site comparison study in Côte d’Ivoire found that a forest managed by thinning had a similar abundance of fruit-feeding butterflies to an unmanaged, naturally regenerating forest.

query: What are the documented effects of thinning trees on the various components of a forest ecosystem, including mature trees, young trees, and understory plants?
relevant_summary: The documented effects of tree thinning on forest ecosystem components vary across different vegetation layers. For mature trees, eleven of twelve studies found that thinning decreased tree density and cover (Action 1209). Five of six studies found that thinning increased tree size (Action 1209). One study found that thinning decreased tree species richness and diversity (Action 1209). For young trees, six of twelve studies found that thinning increased the density of young trees, while one study found decreased density and five found no effect or mixed effects (Action 1210). One study found that thinning increased the growth rate of young trees (Action 1210). For understory plants, seventeen of twenty-five studies found that thinning increased the density and cover of understory plants, while seven studies found no effect or mixed effects and one study found a decrease in herbaceous species abundance (Action 1211). Thirteen of nineteen studies found that thinning increased species richness and diversity of understory plants, while seven studies found no effect (Action 1211).

query: To avoid the impacts of clearcutting in European and North American forests, what are the documented effects of alternative harvesting methods like shelterwood or partial retention harvesting?
relevant_summary: According to studies from European and North American forests, several alternative harvesting methods to clearcutting have documented effects. Shelterwood harvesting shows mixed results across different taxa: for butterflies and moths, one study found higher macro-moth species richness compared to clearcutting (action ID 3871), another found moth species richness recovered faster after shelterwood harvesting than after clearcutting (action ID 3871), while a third found similar moth species richness between shelterwood and clearcutting but lower than unharvested forest (action ID 3871). For salamanders, shelterwood harvesting resulted in higher, similar, or initially higher then similar abundance compared to clearcutting (action ID 851), with a meta-analysis finding that partial harvest including shelterwood resulted in smaller reductions in salamander populations than clearcutting (action ID 851). For plants, shelterwood harvesting in Sweden and USA resulted in higher plant diversity, lower grass cover, and higher density of tree species compared to clearcutting (action ID 1214), and generally increased abundance, species richness, and diversity of understory plants as well as growth and survival rate of young trees (action ID 1223). Partial retention harvesting in Canada decreased the density of young trees compared to clearcutting (action ID 1215). Selective harvesting showed mixed results for mammals, with one study finding no higher small mammal species richness compared to clearcutting (action ID 2637), while results for abundance varied by species and study, with a systematic review finding that partially harvested forests had more red-backed voles but not deer mice than clearcut forests (action ID 2637). Group harvesting studies found that compared to clearcutting, harvesting trees in small groups did not result in higher amphibian or salamander abundance (action ID 844), though a meta-analysis found partial harvest methods including group harvesting resulted in smaller reductions in salamander populations than clearcutting (action ID 844).

query: What is the state of the evidence regarding different methods for restoring forests by adding or encouraging biological material like seeds, plants, or beneficial organisms?
relevant_summary:
Based on the available evidence, different forest restoration methods using biological materials show mixed effectiveness. Regarding seed sowing methods, one study in Brazil found that sowing tree seeds increased the density and species richness of new trees (1244), while three studies in the USA examining post-wildfire seed sowing found it decreased the number and cover of native species and tree seedling density, with no effect on total plant cover or species richness (1236). Combining sowing seeds with planting individual plants showed no increased benefit over either method alone (1700).

For direct planting approaches, replanting native trees in logged areas showed some promise, with similar species richness but lower diversity compared to naturally regenerating secondary forest after nine years (3874). Studies on replanting native vegetation across multiple countries found generally similar species richness and diversity to reference habitats, though some showed lower abundance than remnant native habitat (3933). 

Regarding beneficial organism inoculation, soil mycorrhiza inoculation before seeding/planting showed mixed results - one study found it initially increased vegetation cover but showed no difference after three years, while another found it increased abundance of target conservation species (3429). Studies specifically examining mycorrhizal fungi addition to tree seedlings found no effect on growth and survival in most cases, though one study showed increased growth for red balau seedlings (1841). Research on root-associated fungi for tree seedlings found no evidence of effectiveness (1160, 3350).

Soil preparation methods like scarification or ploughing showed positive effects, with studies finding increased cover and diversity of understory plants and mixed effects on tree species density (1251). Artificial methods to encourage natural seed dispersal, such as building bird perches, showed no significant effect on seedling abundance (1817).

One study evaluated the effects on butterflies and moths of replanting native trees in logged areas. The study was in Ghana.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (1 STUDY)

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)"

{
  "action_id": "3933",
  "action_title": "Replant native vegetation",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Eleven studies evaluated the effects on butterflies and moths of replanting native vegetation. Five studies were in the USA, two were in New Zealand, and one was in each of Switzerland, Mexico, Ecuador and Brazil.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (5 STUDIES)

Community composition (3 studies): One replicated, site comparison study in Ecuador found that native trees planted within recently abandoned pasture and secondary shrubland had a similar community composition of butterflies and moths after 7–8 years, but a subset of communities found on native trees planted within pine plantations, or on saplings regenerating naturally within pristine forest. One replicated, site comparison study in Brazil found that 12–14-year-old replanted and naturally regenerating forests had a different butterfly community to both grazed pasture and remnant forest. One site comparison study in Mexico found that a replanted forest had a different community composition of caterpillars to a naturally regenerating forest.
Richness/diversity (5 studies): Four of five site comparison studies (including four replicated studies) in New Zealand, Mexico, Ecuador, Brazil and the USA found that replanted native shrubs, grasses, non-woody broadleaved plants (forbs) and trees had a similar species richness or diversity of butterflies, caterpillars and flower-visiting insects (including butterflies and moths) to vineyards, pasture, naturally regenerating and remnant forests, and remnant prairies. However, one of these studies also found that the species richness of butterflies in replanted native shrubs and grasslands was lower than in remnant native habitat. The fifth study found that, after 7–8 years, native trees planted in pine plantations had a greater species richness of butterflies and moths than trees planted in recently abandoned pasture, but both had a lower species richness than naturally regenerating saplings within pristine forest.

POPULATION RESPONSE (6 STUDIES)

Abundance (5 studies): Four of five site comparison studies (including four replicated studies) in New Zealand, Mexico and the USA found that replanted native shrubs, grasses, non-woody broadleaved plants (forbs), trees and translocated bamboo rush had a similar abundance of butterflies, caterpillars and flower-visiting insects (including butterflies and moths), and density of Fred the thread moth caterpillars to vineyards, pasture, naturally regenerating forest, remnant prairies and undisturbed bogs. However, one of these studies also found that replanted native shrubs and grasses had a lower abundance of butterflies than remnant native habitat. The fifth study found that common milkweed planted in meadows had fewer monarch butterfly eggs than milkweed planted in private gardens.
Survival (2 studies): Two replicated studies (including one randomized, controlled study and one site comparison study) in the USA found that the survival of common sooty winged skipper and monarch butterfly eggs and caterpillars was similar on planted patches of lamb’s-quarters of different sizes, and on common milkweed planted in meadows or private gardens.
Condition (1 study): One replicated, site comparison study in New Zealand found that Fred the thread moth caterpillars in translocated bamboo rush plants were a similar size to caterpillars in undisturbed bogs.

BEHAVIOUR (3 STUDIES)

Use (3 studies): Three studies in the USA and Switzerland reported that planted patches of silver lupine, prairie violet and bladder senna were used by wild mission blue and Iolas blue butterflies, and translocated regal fritillaries, for at least three or 4–10 years after planting."
}

{
  "action_id": "3429",
  "action_title": "Inoculate soil with mycorrhiza before seeding/planting",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Five studies examined the effects of inoculating soil with mycorrhiza before seeding/planting on grassland vegetation. Four studies were in the USA and one was in Germany.

VEGETATION COMMUNITY (1 STUDY)

Overall richness/diversity (1 study): One replicated, randomized, controlled study in Germany found that inoculating soil with mycorrhizal fungi and sowing seeds of grassland species did not alter plant species richness.

VEGETATION ABUNDANCE (4 STUDIES)

Overall abundance (2 studies): One replicated, randomized, paired, controlled study in the USA found that inoculating soil with mycorrhizal fungi before sowing seeds initially increased vegetation cover, but after three years, vegetation cover did not differ between areas that were and were not inoculated. One controlled study in the USA found that adding soil microbes and nutrients when planting grass plugs did not change the overall cover of herbaceous species.
Characteristic plant abundance (2 studies): One replicated, randomized, controlled study in Germany found that adding mycorrhiza to the soil and sowing seeds of grassland species increased the abundance of target species that were considered a local conservation priority. One controlled study in the USA found that adding soil microbes and nutrients when planting grass plugs increased the cover of three of 38 native prairie species.
Tree/shrub abundance (1 study): One controlled study in the USA found that adding soil microbes and nutrients when planting grass plugs did not change the cover of woody species.
Native/non-target species abundance (1 study): One replicated, controlled study in the USA found that adding mycorrhizal fungi to soil before sowing seeds did not alter the biomass of three native grass and forb species.

VEGETATION STRUCTURE (1 STUDY)

Height (1 study): One replicated, controlled study in the USA found that adding mycorrhizal fungi to soil before sowing seeds increased the height of giant sacaton plants.
Individual plant size (1 study): One replicated, controlled study in the USA found that adding mycorrhizal fungi to soil before sowing seeds did not increase the biomass of giant sacaton plants.

OTHER (1 STUDY) 

Germination/Emergence (1 study): One replicated, controlled study in the USA found that adding mycorrhizal fungi to soil before sowing seeds did not increase the emergence of giant sacaton plants."
}

{
  "action_id": "1251",
  "action_title": "Use soil scarification or ploughing to enhance germination",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Two studies (including one replicated, randomized, controlled study) in Portugal and the USA found that ploughing increased the cover and diversity of understory plants.
Two of three studies (including two replicated, randomized, controlled) in Canada and Brazil found that ploughing increased,  and one found it decreased the density of young trees. Two replicated, controlled studies in Ethiopia and Sweden found mixed effects of tilling on different tree species.
One replicated, before-and-after trial in Finland found that ploughing decreased the cover of plants living on wood surface.
One replicated, controlled study in the USA found that ploughing did not decrease the spreading distance and density of invasive grass seedlings."
}

query: To aid the establishment of newly planted trees in a restoration project, what actions are available to protect them from competition and other threats?
relevant_summary:
Several actions are available to protect newly planted trees from competition and other threats in restoration projects. For competition management, selective thinning after restoration planting can be used (action 1238), and mechanical thinning before or after planting has shown positive results in five of six studies across multiple countries, increasing survival and size of planted trees (action 1261). Ground preparation before tree planting has demonstrated effectiveness, with six of seven studies finding increased survival and growth rates of planted trees (action 1263).

To protect against vegetation competition, covering the ground with plastic mats after restoration planting can decrease the cover of herbaceous plants and grasses (action 1239), while covering with techniques other than plastic mats, such as mulch, increased total plant cover (action 1240). Adding mulch before or after seeding/planting has shown mixed results, with some studies finding increased seedling numbers and target plant species cover (action 3425). Weed mats showed no effect on seedling height in one study (action 1267).

For physical protection, fences or barriers can be used to protect planted vegetation, particularly in wetland environments. Studies in freshwater wetlands found that fencing to exclude deer increased tree seedling height and sometimes improved survival, though effects varied by season, elevation, and site (action 3330). In brackish/saline wetlands, full-length plastic shelters increased survival rates and growth of red mangrove propagules (action 3331). Plastic guards increased height and diameter growth rates in baldcypress seedlings (action 3330).

Additional protection methods include using shading for planted trees, which increased survival rates of native tree seedlings in one study (action 1269). However, some proposed actions lack research evidence, including using tree tubes/small fences/cages to protect individual trees (action 2630), removing competing vegetation in brackish/saline wetlands (action 3335), and planting mixtures of tree species to enhance survival (action 1159).

{
  "action_id": "3330",
  "action_title": "Use fences or barriers to protect freshwater wetlands planted with trees/shrubs",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Five studies evaluated the effects, on vegetation, of using fences or barriers to protect freshwater wetlands planted with trees/shrubs. Four studies were in the USA and one was in Australia.

VEGETATION COMMUNITY
 
VEGETATION ABUNDANCE

Tree/shrub abundance (1 study): One replicated, paired, controlled study in a floodplain swamp clearing in the USA found that amongst plots sown with tree seeds, fencing to exclude deer had no significant effect on total tree seedling density after three years.

VEGETATION STRUCTURE

Height (2 studies): One replicated, paired, controlled study in a floodplain swamp clearing in the USA found that amongst plots sown with tree seeds, those also fenced to exclude deer contained taller tree seedlings, after three years, than those left unfenced. One replicated, paired, controlled study in created freshwater wetlands in the USA found that the average height of white cedar Thuja occidentalis saplings typically increased by a similar amount, between two and five years after planting, in plots fenced to exclude deer and plots left unfenced.

OTHER

Survival (3 studies): One replicated, paired, controlled study in floodplain swamps in Australia reported that planted swamp gum Eucalyptus camphora seedlings had a much higher survival rate, over one year, in plots fenced to exclude mammals than in open plots. Two replicated, paired, controlled studies in freshwater wetlands in the USA reported that exclusion fencing sometimes increased survival of planted tree seedlings but sometimes had no clear or significant effect. This depended on factors such as the season of planting, seedling elevation, and site.
Growth (1 study): One replicated, randomized, controlled study in a nutria-invaded wetland in the USA found that planted baldcypress Taxodium distichum seedlings grew more, over one growing season, when protected than when left unprotected. Plastic guards increased height and diameter growth rates. Sticky, insect-repellent oil increased the growth rate for height, but not diameter."
}

{
  "action_id": "3331",
  "action_title": "Use fences or barriers to protect planted brackish/saline wetlands planted with trees/shrubs",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

One study evaluated the effects, on vegetation, of using fences or barriers to protect brackish/saline wetlands planted with trees/shrubs. The study was in the USA.

VEGETATION COMMUNITY
 
VEGETATION ABUNDANCE
 
VEGETATION STRUCTURE

Height (1 study): One replicated, paired, controlled study in exposed coastal sites in the USA found that red mangrove Rhizophora mangle propagules planted within full-length plastic shelters had grown taller than propagules planted without shelter in three of four comparisons, made 22–129 days after planting.

OTHER

Survival (1 study): One replicated, paired, controlled study in exposed coastal sites in the USA reported that full-length plastic shelters increased the survival rate of planted red mangrove Rhizophora mangle propagules over 4–8 months, but that full-length bamboo shelters and below-ground plastic shelters had no clear effect on survival."
}

query: In the USA, what are the documented effects of different post-harvesting management techniques on young trees and understory vegetation?
relevant_summary:
Based on documented studies in the USA, several post-harvesting management techniques have been evaluated for their effects on young trees and understory vegetation:

Shelterwood harvesting increased abundance, species richness and diversity of understory plants, as well as the growth and survival rate of young trees according to studies including those from the USA (Action 1223). Species richness of macro-moths was higher after shelterwood harvesting than after patch-cutting or clearcutting, with richness similar to thinned and unharvested forests (Action 3871). Moth species richness recovered faster after shelterwood harvesting than after group selection harvesting or clearcutting (Action 3871).

Group-selection harvesting showed mixed results, with some studies finding increased cover and diversity of understory plants and density of young trees, while others found decreased understory species richness and biomass, and still others found no effect on understory species richness and diversity or tree density and growth-rate (Action 1224). Forests managed by group selection harvesting had similar moth species richness to those managed by single tree harvesting or clearcutting, but lower species richness than unharvested forest (Action 3868).

Thinning instead of clearcutting resulted in higher macro-moth species richness compared to patch-cutting or clearcutting, with richness similar to unharvested forests (Action 3868).

Woody debris removal produced variable effects: one study found it increased understory vegetation cover, while three studies found no effect or mixed effects on cover (Action 1213). Four studies found no effect or mixed effects on understory vegetation species richness and diversity, and two found no effect on cover and species diversity of trees (Action 1213). For young trees specifically, one study found debris removal increased young tree density, another found it decreased density, and three studies found mixed effects or no effect on young tree density (Action 1213). One study in Canada found that removal of woody debris increased survival rate of planted trees (Action 1257), while one study in the USA found mixed effects of removing, chopping and burning woody debris on the size of planted trees (Action 1257).

Logging trees within forests increased density and cover of understory plants in five studies, while five studies found no effect or mixed effects (Action 1273). Four studies found that logging increased species richness and diversity of understory plants, while three studies found no effect (Action 1273).

query: As an alternative to using herbicides, what other methods can be used to control vegetation competition for seedlings and young trees?
relevant_summary:
Based on the action documents, several alternative methods to herbicides can be used to control vegetation competition for seedlings and young trees:

Physical/Mechanical Methods: Manual control and removal of midstorey and ground-level vegetation including mowing, chaining, and cutting can be used for vegetation management (Action 337). Cutting and mowing can be specifically applied to control problematic herbaceous plants (Action 3106). Rotovating can be used to control grass vegetation (Action 1648). Physical damage to problematic plants through methods like ploughing and disking has been studied, with some studies finding that managed plots using cutting, disking and herbicide applications contained more non-planted tree seedlings than unmanaged plots (Action 3097).

Manual Weeding: Selective hand weeding can be used to manage vegetation (Action 3714). This involves physically removing competing plants by hand rather than using chemical treatments.

Protective Materials: Weed mats can be used to protect planted trees from vegetation competition (Action 1267). Adding mulch before or after seeding/planting can help control competing vegetation, with some studies finding that mulch increased cover of target plant species and increased seedling numbers (Action 3425).

Site Preparation: Removing vegetation before seeding/planting can improve establishment conditions, with studies showing this increased germination rates of sown species and increased seedling numbers for some species (Action 3416).

These methods provide physical barriers, mechanical removal, or site preparation alternatives to chemical herbicide applications for managing vegetation competition around seedlings and young trees.

query: What are the documented benefits and negative impacts of different forest management interventions studied in Australia?
relevant_summary:
Based on the available action documents, several forest management interventions have been studied in Australia with documented benefits and impacts:

**Tree Thinning in Forests and Woodlands:** Four studies in Australia found that thinning trees generally increased bat activity and diversity compared to unthinned forests (Action 991). Forest thinned up to 20 years previously had higher bat diversity than unthinned forest, though sites thinned more than 20 years previously did not differ. Forest thinned up to eight years previously or more than 20 years previously had higher bat activity than unthinned forest, but sites thinned 8-20 years previously did not differ. One study found the same bat species in thinned and unthinned forest, except for the chocolate wattled bat, which was not recorded in forests with unthinned regrowth.

**Prescribed Fire Management:** Studies in Australia documented several effects of prescribed burning. In eucalyptus forest, selective burning resulted in fewer Eltham copper caterpillars in the spring following burning compared to before burning (Action 3877). Three studies in Australia found that prescribed burning in forest, open woodland and savanna had mixed effects on reptile populations (Action 3646). One study found that reptile abundance increased with time since burning, while others found similar reptile species richness in burned versus unburned areas. One study found that areas of woodland managed by burning and vegetation thinning had higher reptile species richness than unmanaged areas (Action 3655).

**Burning Timing Effects:** One study in Australia found that in forest burned early in the dry season, northern brown bandicoot survival rate declined less than in forests burned late in the dry season (Action 2416).

**Woody Debris Addition:** A randomised, replicated, controlled study from Australia found that brown treecreeper numbers were higher in plots with large amounts of dead wood added, compared to control plots or those with less debris added (Action 344).

**Grazing Cessation:** Two studies in Australia examining the cessation of livestock grazing in forest, open woodland and savanna found mixed results for reptiles (Action 3511). Studies found that ungrazed and grazed areas had similar reptile species richness and diversity, though grazing had mixed effects on reptile abundance.

**Combined Management Approaches:** Studies in Australia found that areas managed by burning in combination with vegetation cutting had mixed effects on reptile populations, with some showing similar abundance compared to burning only or unmanaged areas (Action 3655).

  "action_title": "Use prescribed burning: Forest, open woodland & savanna",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Twenty-eight studies evaluated the effects of using prescribed burning in forest, open woodland and savanna on reptile populations. Twenty-four studies were in the USA, three were in Australia and one was in Brazil.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (12 STUDIES)

Community composition (1 study): One replicated, randomized, controlled, before-and-after study in the USA found that in areas with prescribed burning, reptile assemblages became similar to more pristine areas that had historically experienced frequent fires.
Richness/diversity (11 studies): Seven studies (including two replicated, randomized, controlled, before-and-after studies) in the USA and Australia found that burned areas had similar reptile species richness compared to unburned areas. One of the studies also found that burned areas had higher reptile diversity than unburned areas. Two replicated studies (including one randomized, controlled study) in Australia and the USA found that reptile species richness remained similar with time since burning. One of two studies (including one replicated, randomized, controlled, before-and-after study) in the USA found that burned areas had higher combined reptile and amphibian species richness than unburned areas. The other study found that burned areas had similar combined reptile and amphibian species richness and diversity compared to unburned areas.

POPULATION RESPONSE (26 STUDIES)

Abundance (23 studies): Nine of 21 studies (including four replicated, randomized, controlled, before-and-after studies) in the USA and Australia found that burning had mixed effects on the abundance of reptiles, six-lined racerunners and western yellow-bellied racer snakes. Six studies found that burned areas had a higher abundance of reptiles, lizards, black racer snakes and more active gopher tortoise burrows compared to unburned areas. The other six studies found that burned areas had a similar abundance of reptiles, lizards and gopher tortoise burrows compared to unburned areas. One replicated, site comparison study in Australia found that reptile abundance increased with time since burning. One replicated, randomized, controlled study in the USA found that burning in different seasons had mixed effects on the abundance of reptiles.
Survival (2 study): One of two studies (one site comparison and one controlled study) in the USA and Brazil found that Texas horned lizard survival was similar in burned and unburned areas. The other study found that burning had mixed effects on survival of an endemic lizard species.
Condition (1 study): One site comparison study in the USA found that eastern fence lizards in recently burned areas ran faster than those from areas that were burned less recently or were unburned.

BEHAVIOUR (2 STUDIES)

Behaviour change (2 studies): One replicated, controlled, before and-after study in the USA found that burning affected overwintering habitat use by gopher tortoises. One replicated, controlled study in the USA found that in burned areas, black racer snakes had higher surface activity than in unburned areas."
}

{
  "action_id": "3655",
  "action_title": "Use prescribed burning in combination with vegetation cutting",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Ten studies evaluated the effects of using prescribed burning in combination with vegetation cutting on reptile populations. Eight studies were in the USA and two were in Australia.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (5 STUDIES)

Community composition (1 study): One replicated, randomized, controlled, before-and-after study in the USA found that cutting vegetation prior to burning resulted in reptile assemblages becoming similar to areas with more pristine habitat and a history of frequent fires.
Richness/diversity (5 studies): Four of five replicated studies (including three randomized, controlled studies) in Australia and the USA found that areas managed by burning in combination with vegetation cutting had similar reptile species richness compared to either burning only, cutting only or areas that were unmanaged. The other study found that areas of woodland managed by burning and vegetation thinning had higher reptile species richness than unmanaged areas.

POPULATION RESPONSE (9 STUDIES)

Abundance (9 studies): Four of nine replicated studies (including five randomized, controlled studies) in the USA and Australia found that areas that were managed by burning in combination with vegetation cutting had a higher abundance of overall reptiles, lizards, eastern fence lizards and five-lined skinks compared to areas that were either only burned or unmanaged. Three studies found a similar abundance of overall reptiles, snakes and turtles compared to either burning only, cutting only or unmanaged. Four studies found mixed effects of burning in combination with vegetation cutting on the abundance of reptiles and six-lined racerunners.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)"
}

{
  "action_id": "2416",
  "action_title": "Burn at specific time of year",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Two studies evaluated the effects on mammals of burning at a specific time of year. One study was in Australia, and one was in the USA.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (0 STUDIES)
POPULATION RESPONSE (1 STUDY)

Abundance (1 study): A replicated, randomized, controlled, before-and-after study in the USA found that carrying out prescribed burns in autumn did not increase small mammal abundances or biomass relative to burning in summer.
Survival (1 study): A randomized, replicated, controlled study in Australia found that in forest burned early in the dry season, northern brown bandicoot survival rate declined less than in forests burned late in the dry season.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)"
}

{
  "action_id": "3511",
  "action_title": "Cease livestock grazing: Forest, open woodland & savanna",
  "key_messages": "Key Messages:

Five studies evaluated the effects of ceasing livestock grazing in forest, open woodland and savanna on reptile populations. Two studies were in each of Argentina and Australia and one was in Mexico1.

COMMUNITY RESPONSE (4 STUDIES)

Richness/diversity (4 studies): Three of four studies (including two replicated, site-comparison studies) in Mexico, Argentina and Australia found that ungrazed and grazed areas, in one case with burning, had similar reptile species richness and diversity. The other study found that in areas where livestock grazing was stopped, combined reptile and small mammal species richness increased more than in areas with grazing.

POPULATION RESPONSE (5 STUDIES)

Abundance (5 studies): Two of five studies (including three replicated, site comparison studies) in Mexico, Argentina and Australia found that ungrazed areas had a higher abundance of reptiles and lizards than grazed areas. Two studies found that ungrazed areas, in one case with burning, had similar overall reptile or reptile and small mammal abundance compared to grazed areas. The other study found that grazing had mixed effects on reptile abundance.

BEHAVIOUR (0 STUDIES)"
}

Forest thinned up to eight years previously or more than 20 years previously had higher bat activity than unthinned forest, but sites thinned 8-20 years previously did not differ. One study found the same bat species in thinned and unthinned forest, except for the chocolate wattled bat, which was not recorded in forests with unthinned regrowth.

**Prescribed Fire Management:** Studies in Australia documented several effects of prescribed burning. In eucalyptus forest, selective burning resulted in fewer Eltham copper caterpillars in the spring following burning compared to before burning (Action 3877). Three studies in Australia found that prescribed burning in forest, open woodland and savanna had mixed effects on reptile populations (Action 3646). One study found that reptile abundance increased with time since burning, while others found similar reptile species richness in burned versus unburned areas. One study found that areas of woodland managed by burning and vegetation thinning had higher reptile species richness than unmanaged areas (Action 3655).

**Burning Timing Effects:** One study in Australia found that in forest burned early in the dry season, northern brown bandicoot survival rate declined less than in forests burned late in the dry season (Action 2416).

**Woody Debris Addition:** A randomised, replicated, controlled study from Australia found that brown treecreeper numbers were higher in plots with large amounts of dead wood added, compared to control plots or those with less debris added (Action 344).

**Grazing Cessation:** Two studies in Australia examining the cessation of livestock grazing in forest, open woodland and savanna found mixed results for reptiles (Action 3511). Studies found that ungrazed and grazed areas had similar reptile species richness and diversity, though grazing had mixed effects on reptile abundance.

**Combined Management Approaches:** Studies in Australia found that areas managed by burning in combination with vegetation cutting had mixed effects on reptile populations, with some showing similar abundance compared to burning only or unmanaged areas (Action 3655).", "action_ids": ["991","3877","3646","2416","344","3511","3655"]}

query: How do mechanical removal and herbicide application compare in their effectiveness for controlling understory vegetation after tree planting?
relevant_summary: Based on the available evidence, both mechanical removal and herbicide application show mixed effectiveness for controlling understory vegetation after tree planting. For mechanical removal after tree planting, five studies found no effect on emergence, survival, growth rate or frost damage in planted seedlings, though one study found removing competing herbs increased seedling biomass (Action 1256). One study found that removal of sheep laurel shrubs increased growth rate and height of planted black spruce seedlings (Action 1256). For herbicide application after tree planting, two of three studies found that using herbicide increased the size of planted trees, while one study found no effect on tree size (Action 1262). One study found no effect of herbicide use on frost damage to planted Norway spruce seedlings (Action 1262). When vegetation removal is combined with mechanical soil disturbance, two studies found this increased cover and diversity of understory plants and decreased understory shrub cover, and one study found it increased density of young trees (Action 1274). Pre-planting herbicide application shows some promise, with studies finding it increased sown species richness and cover of sown grass species, and increased seedling emergence for five of eight wildflower species (Action 3418).

query: What are the observed effects of adding soil amendments or ground coverings, such as organic matter, lime, or straw, after tree planting?
relevant_summary:
Based on the available evidence, soil amendments and ground coverings after tree planting show varied effects:

**Straw ground covering:** One replicated, randomized, controlled study in the Czech Republic found that covering the ground with straw increased the growth rate of planted trees and shrubs, while bark or fleece did not have this effect (Action 1266).

**Organic matter amendments:** In freshwater wetlands, adding large amounts of compost to plots planted with tree seedlings resulted in plant communities characteristic of drier conditions and lower plant species richness and diversity after three years, while birch saplings were larger in plots with large amounts of compost compared to unamended plots (Action 3310). In brackish/saline wetlands, adding manure to plots planted with tree seedlings had mixed effects on survival and growth over three years, depending on the tree species and manure dose (Action 3311).

**Surface mulching:** In freshwater wetlands, mulching with woodchips before planting native shrubs had no significant effect on overall cover, swamp gum cover, or seedling height after one year (Action 3314).

**Lime application:** One of two replicated, randomized, controlled studies in the USA found that adding lime before restoration planting decreased the survival of pine seedlings, while the other study found no effect of adding lime on planted oak seedling growth (Action 1259).

**Fresh plant material:** Addition of crop remains and straw showed increased microbial biomass, improved soil structure when straw was incorporated, and higher carbon levels when plant material was added to soil (Action 910).

Biodiversity: One randomized, replicated experiment from Belgium found increased microbial biomass when crop remains and straw were added.
Compaction: One study from India found improved soil structure when straw was incorporated. One before-and-after trial from the UK found that incorporating straw residues by discing (reduced tillage) did not improve anaerobic soils (low oxygen levels) in compacted soils.
Erosion: Two randomized, replicated studies from Canada and India measured the effect of incorporating straw on erosion. One found straw addition reduced soil loss, and one found mixed effects depending on soil type.
Nutrient loss: Four replicated studies from Belgium, the UK and the USA (one also controlled, one also randomized, and two also controlled and randomized) reported higher soil nitrogen levels when compost or straw was applied, but mixed results when processed wastes were added. Soil organic carbon: Six studies from China, Denmark and India measured the effect of incorporating plant material into the soil. One found higher carbon levels when straw was applied along with NPK fertilizers. One also found larger soil aggregates. One replicated study from China and the Philippines found mixed results depending on site.
Yield: One replicated trial from Denmark found higher barley yield when straw was incorporated. One trial from the Philippines found higher grain yields when crop remains were incorporated earlier in the season.

Biodiversity: Five controlled trials from China and India (four also randomized and replicated), and one study from Japan found higher microbial biomass and activity in soils with a mix of manure and inorganic fertilizers. Erosion: One controlled, replicated trial from India found that mixed amendments were more effective at reducing the size of cracks in dry soil than inorganic fertilizers alone or no fertilizer.
SOC loss: Four controlled, randomized, replicated trials and one controlled trial from China and India found more organic carbon in soils with mixed fertilizers. Manure alone also increased organic carbon. One trial also found more carbon in soil amended with inorganic fertilizers and lime.
SOM loss: Two controlled, randomized, replicated trials from China and India found more nutrients in soils with manure and inorganic fertilizers. One controlled, randomized, replicated trial from China found inconsistent effects of using mixed manure and inorganic fertilizers.

Six studies evaluated the effects on peatland vegetation of liming areas planted with peatland plants. Four studies involved fen plants, one involved bog plants and one involved peat swamp plants. Two of the studies were in greenhouses/nurseries.
Survival (2 studies): One replicated, controlled study in the Netherlands reported that liming typically reduced survival of planted fen herbs after two growing seasons. One replicated, randomized, paired, controlled study in Sweden found that liming increased survival of planted fen mosses over one growing season.
Growth (3 studies): Two controlled, before-and-after studies found that liming did not increase growth of planted peatland vegetation. Liming reduced or had no effect on Sphagnum moss growth in bog pools in the UK, and reduced growth rates for the majority of peat swamp tree seedlings in a nursery in Indonesia. One replicated, controlled, before-and-after study in Sweden found that liming increased growth of planted fen mosses.
Cover (2 studies): One replicated, randomized, paired, controlled, before-and-after study in a fen in Sweden found that liming increased cover of sown mosses. However, one replicated, randomized, paired, controlled study in a bog in Canada found that liming plots sown with fen vegetation fragments had no effect on total vegetation, vascular plant or bryophyte cover."
}

query: What is the evidence on the long-term effectiveness of using tree guards to protect planted trees?
relevant_summary: Evidence on the long-term effectiveness of tree guards for protecting planted trees shows mixed results. One replicated, randomized, controlled study in the USA found that using light but not dark coloured plastic tree shelters increased the survival rate of planted tree seedlings (Action 1268). One replicated, controlled study in Hong Kong found that tree guards increased tree height after 37 but not 44 months (Action 1268). For wetland applications, one replicated, paired, controlled study in exposed coastal sites in the USA found that full-length plastic shelters increased the survival rate of planted red mangrove propagules over 4-8 months, but that full-length bamboo shelters and below-ground plastic shelters had no clear effect on survival (Action 3331). The same study found that red mangrove propagules planted within full-length plastic shelters had grown taller than propagules planted without shelter in three of four comparisons, made 22-129 days after planting (Action 3331). One replicated, randomized, controlled study in a nutria-invaded wetland in the USA found that planted baldcypress seedlings grew more over one growing season when protected than when left unprotected, with plastic guards increasing height and diameter growth rates (Action 3330).

Five studies evaluated the effects, on vegetation, of using fences or barriers to protect freshwater wetlands planted with trees/shrubs. Four studies were in the USA and one was in Australia.

VEGETATION COMMUNITY
 
VEGETATION ABUNDANCE

Tree/shrub abundance (1 study): One replicated, paired, controlled study in a floodplain swamp clearing in the USA found that amongst plots sown with tree seeds, fencing to exclude deer had no significant effect on total tree seedling density after three years.

VEGETATION STRUCTURE

Height (2 studies): One replicated, paired, controlled study in a floodplain swamp clearing in the USA found that amongst plots sown with tree seeds, those also fenced to exclude deer contained taller tree seedlings, after three years, than those left unfenced. One replicated, paired, controlled study in created freshwater wetlands in the USA found that the average height of white cedar Thuja occidentalis saplings typically increased by a similar amount, between two and five years after planting, in plots fenced to exclude deer and plots left unfenced.

OTHER

Survival (3 studies): One replicated, paired, controlled study in floodplain swamps in Australia reported that planted swamp gum Eucalyptus camphora seedlings had a much higher survival rate, over one year, in plots fenced to exclude mammals than in open plots. Two replicated, paired, controlled studies in freshwater wetlands in the USA reported that exclusion fencing sometimes increased survival of planted tree seedlings but sometimes had no clear or significant effect. This depended on factors such as the season of planting, seedling elevation, and site.
Growth (1 study): One replicated, randomized, controlled study in a nutria-invaded wetland in the USA found that planted baldcypress Taxodium distichum seedlings grew more, over one growing season, when protected than when left unprotected. Plastic guards increased height and diameter growth rates. Sticky, insect-repellent oil increased the growth rate for height, but not diameter."
